abstracts.cdata!:
The Education Reform Project for Bolivia
            had the following ratings: the outcome was unsatisfactory,
            the sustainability was highly likely, the institutional
            development impact was high, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. The lessons learned
            indicate that when disseminating a new strategy for
            innovation, choice is an important instrument. Relations
            with teacher unions are fundamental in education reform.
            Bringing parents into the schools with some kind of decision
            making power was fundamental for Bolivia's educational
            achievements. Not having a Project Implementation Unit was a
            correct decision. While the Project was implemented with
            excellent development results despite the operational
            problems in procurement and financial management, there is
            no doubt that the lack of a competent team in these areas
            within the Ministry was a major obstacle. The presence and
            continuity of high-quality technical teams was fundamental.
            An adequate education information system is fundamental. The
            Education Quality Measurement and Evaluation system
            (SIMECAL) is a high quality assessment system, but its
            impact have been modest due to its awkward institutional
            placement. The SIMECAL was neither created entirely outside
            the Ministry so as to ensure total impartiality nor within
            the Ministry decision structure so as to provide guidance
            for educational policy decisions.
